title: Adderley Wilkinson
text:
Adderley Edward Wilkinson (Q3 1887 – 1 April 1978) was an Irish <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class cricket</a>er.
Wilkinson was born at <a href="Dunshaughlin">Dunshaughlin</a> in <a href="County%20Meath">County Meath</a> in the third quarter of 1887, and later studied at <a href="Trinity%20College%2C%20Dublin">Trinity College, Dublin</a>, where he played <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> for <a href="Dublin%20University%20Football%20Club">Dublin University Football Club</a>. Graduating as with a degree in engineering, he later played <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class cricket</a> in <a href="British%20India">British India</a> for the <a href="Europeans%20cricket%20team">Europeans</a> against the <a href="Indians%20cricket%20team">Indians</a> at <a href="M.%20A.%20Chidambaram%20Stadium">Madras</a> in December 1920. Batting twice in the match, Wilkinson <a href="Batting_order_%28cricket%29%23Opening_batsmen">opened the batting</a> in the Europeans first-innings, and was <a href="duck%20%28cricket%29">dismissed without scoring</a> by <a href="C.%20R.%20Ganapathy">C. R. Ganapathy</a>. <a href="Follow-on">Following-on</a> in their second-innings, he was dismissed by <a href="C.%20K.%20Krishnaswamy">C. K. Krishnaswamy</a> for 5 runs. Fellow Irishman <a href="John%20Tudor%20Gwynn">John Gwynn</a> was also a member of the Europeans team. Outside of cricket, he worked as an engineer and an actor. He died at <a href="Enniskerry">Enniskerry</a> in April 1978.
